description: Department of Defense Small Business Innovation Research Phase I (Air Force, Space Force)

technical_abstract.name: Technical Abstract
technical_abstract.guidelines: Write a 1-page technical abstract that speaks DoD language from the first sentence. STRUCTURE: (1) Capability gap being addressed - reference specific BAA topic, DoD requirement, or mission need; (2) Technical approach in operational terms; (3) Military utility - how warfighters will use this; (4) TRL advancement expected (e.g., TRL 3→4); (5) Phase III transition path. CRITICAL: DoD reviewers are often military officers or DoD civilians. They think in terms of missions, not markets. Lead with the military problem, not your technology. Use DoD terminology correctly: SWaP-C, CONOPS, PEO, PM. AVOID: Academic language, commercial-first framing, vague 'military applications.'
technical_abstract.description: Technical summary emphasizing military utility and transition potential
winning_examples: BAD: 'We propose an innovative AI solution with military applications.'

GOOD: 'This effort addresses the Air Force's critical need for real-time threat detection in contested electromagnetic environments (BAA Topic AF###). Our approach advances sensor fusion from TRL 3 to TRL 4, enabling 10x faster target identification with 40% reduction in SWaP. Phase III transition planned with PEO Digital, AFRL Sensors Directorate as transition partner (letter attached).'
technical_abstract.reviewer_psychology: DoD reviewers ask: 'How does this help the warfighter?' Technology for its own sake doesn't impress them. They want to see you understand their mission, their constraints, and how they actually acquire and deploy capability.

identification_and_significance.name: Identification and Significance of Problem
identification_and_significance.guidelines: Clearly identify the DoD problem with evidence of operational impact. STRUCTURE: (1) Specific capability gap - reference DoD requirements documents (BAA, AoA, CPD, CDD) or named military programs; (2) Current state and why inadequate - what do warfighters do now and why doesn't it work; (3) Operational consequences of the gap - missions that can't be performed, lives at risk, costs incurred; (4) Why this problem is significant NOW - alignment with DoD modernization priorities (JADC2, ABMS, digital engineering, etc.). CRITICAL: Show you've studied the operational context. Name specific platforms, missions, or programs affected. AVOID: Generic 'the military needs better X' without specifics.
identification_and_significance.description: Problem definition anchored in specific DoD requirements and operational impact
winning_examples: BAD: 'Current military systems have performance limitations.'

GOOD: 'The F-35's current EW suite requires 3.2 seconds for threat classification in dense signal environments, exceeding the 1-second requirement identified in the Joint Air-to-Ground Missile (JAGM) Analysis of Alternatives. This gap affects 2,400+ aircraft across USAF, USN, and allied forces. Our approach directly addresses JADC2 Priority Area 3 (sensor-to-shooter latency) and aligns with AFRL's Autonomy in Contested Environments initiative.'
identification_and_significance.reviewer_psychology: DoD reviewers want proof you understand THEIR problem, not a generic problem. Reference to specific documents, programs, and requirements signals you've done your homework. It also helps them see the transition path.

technical_objectives.name: Phase I Technical Objectives
technical_objectives.guidelines: Define specific, measurable Phase I objectives that prove feasibility. STRUCTURE: (1) Clear TRL advancement plan - state current TRL with evidence, target TRL with exit criteria; (2) Numbered technical objectives with specific performance targets (use military-relevant metrics); (3) Technical approach for each objective - methodology that considers operational environment; (4) Success criteria tied to military requirements; (5) Risk matrix: Risk | Probability | Impact | Mitigation - DoD expects realistic risk assessment; (6) SWaP-C considerations if applicable. CRITICAL: Objectives must be achievable in 6 months with $200K. Scope narrowly. FATAL FLAWS: Academic research without operational application, ignoring SWaP-C, unrealistic TRL claims, missing risk mitigation.
technical_objectives.description: Measurable objectives with TRL advancement plan and military-relevant success criteria
winning_examples: GOOD: 'Objective 1: Demonstrate signal classification accuracy ≥95% in contested EM environment. Current State: TRL 3 (lab demonstration, 87% accuracy in benign conditions). Phase I Exit Criteria: (a) ≥95% classification accuracy against Red Team signal library, (b) Processing latency <500ms on embedded hardware proxy, (c) Power consumption <15W steady-state. Risk: Adversarial signal spoofing (High probability, High impact). Mitigation: Anti-spoofing techniques from DARPA RadioML program; team includes Dr. X who developed core countermeasures.'
technical_objectives.reviewer_psychology: DoD technical reviewers want to see operational realism. Lab demonstrations are nice, but they care about field conditions. TRL claims must be defensible. Risk acknowledgment shows maturity; hiding risks shows naivety.

work_plan.name: Work Plan
work_plan.guidelines: Provide month-by-month work plan demonstrating project management capability. STRUCTURE: (1) Gantt chart showing tasks, dependencies, milestones; (2) Month-by-month breakdown with specific activities; (3) Milestone table: Milestone | Month | Deliverable | Success Criteria | Verification Method; (4) Go/No-Go decision points - what would trigger a pivot; (5) DoD reporting alignment - how you'll meet contract reporting requirements; (6) Resource allocation by task. CRITICAL: DoD contracts have reporting requirements (monthly technical reports, Phase I Final Report). Show you understand this. Milestones must have QUANTIFIED success criteria. AVOID: Vague timelines, compressed schedules without justification, missing dependencies.
work_plan.description: Detailed work plan with DoD-compliant milestones and reporting
winning_examples: GOOD: 'Month 1: (a) Finalize algorithm architecture per Objective 1 requirements, (b) Establish test harness using AFRL-provided signal library, (c) Monthly Technical Report #1 to TPOC. Milestone M1 (end Month 2): Algorithm achieves 90% accuracy on training set, passes code review. Go/No-Go: If training accuracy <85%, pivot to ensemble approach (2-week buffer allocated). Month 3: (a) Red Team evaluation against adversarial signals, (b) Begin embedded hardware integration...'
work_plan.reviewer_psychology: DoD program managers have been burned by contractors who promise and don't deliver. A detailed work plan with realistic buffers and clear decision points shows you know how to execute. Vague plans signal risk.

related_work.name: Related Work
related_work.guidelines: Demonstrate awareness of competitive landscape including DoD-funded efforts. STRUCTURE: (1) State-of-the-art in this technical area - academic and commercial; (2) Related DoD programs and investments (DARPA, service labs, other SBIRs); (3) Your differentiation - specific technical advantages over each alternative; (4) How this builds on prior work - yours and others; (5) Why existing solutions are inadequate for this military need. CRITICAL: DoD reviewers know what else has been funded. Show you know too. Explain why your approach is different AND better. AVOID: 'No competitors exist' (always false), ignoring DoD-funded alternatives.
related_work.description: Competitive analysis including DoD-funded alternatives with clear differentiation
winning_examples: BAD: 'No similar technology exists in the market.'

GOOD: 'Current approaches: (1) Company X's system (DoD contract #W911xxx): Achieves 85% accuracy but requires 3U form factor and 50W power; (2) DARPA RadioML program: Demonstrated 90% accuracy but processing latency exceeds 2 seconds; (3) Academic state-of-art (Smith et al., 2023): 92% accuracy in simulation only, no hardware demonstration. Our approach: First to combine [technique A] with [technique B], enabling 95% accuracy in 1U form factor at 15W. Preliminary results (Appendix B) demonstrate 89% accuracy in lab tests, with clear path to 95% through Phase I optimization.'
related_work.reviewer_psychology: DoD reviewers are skeptical of 'revolutionary' claims. They've funded many SBIRs and know what's out there. Honest competitive analysis that shows awareness of alternatives AND clear differentiation builds credibility.

dual_use_applications.name: Dual Use and Commercialization
dual_use_applications.guidelines: Describe Phase III transition and dual-use potential. STRUCTURE: (1) Phase III DoD Customer - NAME the PEO, PM, or acquisition program with evidence of engagement (LOI strongly recommended); (2) Military platforms and programs that would use this - be specific; (3) Dual-use commercial applications - reduces DoD risk if commercial market exists; (4) Transition timeline - how Phase I leads to Phase II leads to Phase III; (5) Commercialization team capability. CRITICAL: DoD's purpose is getting capability to warfighters, not funding research. Phase III path is ESSENTIAL. Named transition partners with letters are powerful. FATAL FLAWS: 'We will pursue transition opportunities in Phase II' (too vague), no understanding of acquisition process.
dual_use_applications.description: Clear Phase III transition path with named DoD customers and dual-use applications
winning_examples: BAD: 'This technology has numerous military and commercial applications.'

GOOD: 'Phase III Path: Transition to F-35 EW upgrade program via PEO Tactical Aircraft (letter of interest from Mr. John Smith, PEO-T Acquisition PM, attached). Alternative insertion: Navy SEWIP Block IV has identified this capability gap in their 2024 AoA. Commercial Markets: FAA NextGen requires similar signal processing for ADS-B verification ($340M annual market); LOI from Honeywell Aerospace for $150K pilot pending Phase I success. Transition Timeline: Phase II (24 months) delivers prototype for AFRL evaluation; Phase III ($2-5M anticipated) produces qualification units for operational test.'
dual_use_applications.reviewer_psychology: DoD's #1 frustration with SBIR: technologies that never transition. Reviewers heavily weight evidence of transition path. Named contacts at PEOs/PMs with letters are gold. Dual-use de-risks DoD investment.

company_capabilities.name: Company Capabilities and Experience
company_capabilities.guidelines: Prove you can deliver on DoD contracts. STRUCTURE: (1) Relevant DoD contract history - list contract numbers, values, technical areas, performance; (2) Facilities for this work - lab space, equipment, security infrastructure; (3) Quality management and certifications (ISO, AS9100, CMMI if applicable); (4) Security clearance status - facility clearance, personnel clearances, or path to obtain; (5) ITAR/EAR compliance experience; (6) Previous SBIR/STTR success - Phase I to Phase II conversions, Phase III transitions. CRITICAL: Prior DoD performance is the strongest evidence you can deliver. If first DoD contract, emphasize related commercial work and team DoD experience.
company_capabilities.description: DoD contract history and infrastructure demonstrating delivery capability
winning_examples: BAD: 'Our company has extensive experience in the technology sector.'

GOOD: 'DoD Contract Performance: (1) AFRL Phase II FA8650-XX-C-XXXX ($1.5M): Delivered signal processing algorithms 2 months early, exceeded accuracy requirements by 12%, received 'Excellent' CPARS rating; (2) Navy SBIR Phase I N00014-XX-C-XXXX ($200K): Successfully transitioned to Phase II. Facilities: 5,000 sq ft facility in Dayton, OH with active Secret Facility Clearance (FCL). Equipment includes SIGINT development lab with $2M in test equipment. Personnel: CEO holds active TS/SCI; PI and two engineers hold Secret clearances. ITAR compliance: Registered with DDTC, experienced with ITAR-controlled projects.'
company_capabilities.reviewer_psychology: DoD reviewers assess risk. Prior successful DoD contracts dramatically reduce perceived risk. Security infrastructure matters for sensitive work. CPARS ratings and Phase II conversion rates are tracked.

key_personnel.name: Key Personnel
key_personnel.guidelines: Provide bios emphasizing DoD-relevant experience. FOR EACH PERSON: (1) Name, title, role, clearance status; (2) Education and relevant technical expertise; (3) DoD experience - prior contracts, military service, lab experience; (4) Relevant technical accomplishments and publications; (5) Specific responsibilities on this effort; (6) % effort commitment. CRITICAL: PI must be U.S. citizen for most DoD work. Highlight any military service, DoD civilian experience, or cleared status. Show how team collectively covers all technical needs. AVOID: Generic bios without DoD connection.
key_personnel.description: Team qualifications emphasizing DoD experience and security status
winning_examples: BAD: 'Dr. Smith is an experienced engineer.'

GOOD: 'Dr. Jane Smith, PI (U.S. Citizen, Active Secret Clearance): PhD MIT 2010, RF Systems. DoD Experience: 8 years at AFRL Sensors Directorate leading EW algorithm development; PI on 3 successful SBIR Phase IIs with Phase III transitions totaling $4.2M. Publications: 15 peer-reviewed papers on signal processing, including Smith et al. (2022) which forms the technical basis for this proposal. Role: Technical lead for Objectives 1-2, customer interface, 50% effort. Clearance: Active Secret (TS/SCI eligible).'
key_personnel.reviewer_psychology: Team is critical for DoD. Military or DoD civilian experience signals understanding of the customer. Cleared status matters for classified or sensitive work. Prior SBIR success proves execution capability.

budget_justification.name: Cost Proposal and Budget Justification
budget_justification.guidelines: Provide detailed cost proposal per DoD requirements. STRUCTURE: (1) Direct Labor - name, title, hours, rate, justification for each person. PI minimum 20% effort required; (2) Fringe Benefits - rate and basis; (3) Materials - itemized with justification; (4) Equipment - items >$5K with quotes and justification; (5) Travel - itemize each trip: destination, purpose, cost breakdown; (6) Subcontractors - name, scope, cost, justification. Must be <33% for small business majority; (7) Consultants - name, rate, hours, expertise; (8) Other Direct Costs - itemized; (9) Indirect Costs - rate and basis (negotiated rate or provisional); (10) Fee/Profit - typically 7-10% for SBIR. CRITICAL: Budget must align with work plan. Costs must be allowable per FAR. Show your work on calculations.
budget_justification.description: FAR-compliant cost proposal with detailed justifications
winning_examples: GOOD: 'Direct Labor ($98,400): Dr. Jane Smith, PI, 400 hrs @ $95/hr = $38,000 (50% effort) - leads algorithm development per Objectives 1-2; John Doe, Senior Engineer, 480 hrs @ $75/hr = $36,000 - hardware integration per Objective 3... Materials ($15,000): FPGA development boards (2) @ $3,500 ea = $7,000 - required for embedded implementation; Signal generator rental @ $8,000/6 mo - testing per Milestone M3... Indirect Costs ($35,280): Provisional rate 45% of direct labor, pending DCAA audit... Fee ($14,868): 10% of total cost...'
budget_justification.reviewer_psychology: DoD cost reviewers verify FAR compliance and alignment with technical work. Unexplained costs raise flags. Well-documented budgets with clear calculations build confidence you'll manage the contract properly.

technical_merit.description: Technical excellence and innovation - can you do it?
sub_criteria: Soundness and technical merit of proposed approach
Qualifications of proposed personnel and adequacy of available facilities
Feasibility of achieving Phase I technical objectives within 6 months
Realism of proposed costs in relation to proposed research
Adequacy of Phase I effort for Phase II
what_reviewers_actually_look_for: TRL assessment is accurate and advancement plan is realistic
Technical objectives are specific and measurable
Methodology considers operational environment constraints
Risk identification is comprehensive with credible mitigations
Team has demonstrated relevant technical expertise
common_rejection_reasons: Academic research without path to fieldable capability
Scope too ambitious for Phase I

dod_relevance.description: Relevance to DoD mission and needs - does DoD need it?
sub_criteria: Potential contribution to DoD mission
Alignment with specific DoD requirements or capability gaps
Military utility and operational impact
Transition potential to DoD acquisition programs
Dual-use potential
what_reviewers_actually_look_for: Specific capability gap or military need identified with references
Understanding of operational context and warfighter needs
Alignment with DoD modernization priorities (JADC2, digital transformation)
Named military programs or platforms that need this capability
Evidence of DoD customer engagement
common_rejection_reasons: No reference to DoD requirements or programs
No understanding of how DoD would use this

commercialization.description: Commercial potential and Phase III path - will it transition?
sub_criteria: Potential for commercial success
Market size and opportunity
Company's commercialization plan and capability
Path to Phase III (DoD sales) and beyond
Dual-use applications
what_reviewers_actually_look_for: Named Phase III transition partner with evidence of engagement
Identified acquisition program or PEO/PM contact
Realistic acquisition pathway understanding
Dual-use commercial applications that de-risk DoD investment
Prior transition success
common_rejection_reasons: No understanding of DoD acquisition process
Vague 'will pursue opportunities in Phase II'
No evidence of DoD customer engagement

team_capability.description: Team qualifications and resources - can this team deliver?
sub_criteria: Qualifications of Principal Investigator
Company's relevant experience and past performance
Adequacy of facilities and equipment
Ability to execute and deliver results
Prior DoD contract performance if applicable
what_reviewers_actually_look_for: Prior DoD contract performance with positive ratings
Team members with military or DoD civilian experience
Security clearance status appropriate for the work
Prior SBIR success (Phase I to II conversion, Phase III transition)
Facilities and equipment to perform proposed work
common_rejection_reasons: Missing security clearances for sensitive work
No evidence of ability to execute DoD contracts

special_requirements.security_clearance: Not required for Phase I, may be needed for classified work
special_requirements.u.s._citizen_pi: Principal Investigator must be U.S. citizen
special_requirements.small_business_prime: Small business must be prime contractor
special_requirements.itar_compliance: May be required depending on topic
special_requirements.pi_minimum_effort: Minimum 20% time commitment during Phase I

submission_requirements.letters_of_support: Strongly encouraged - transition partner letters are highly valuable
submission_requirements.pi_commitment: Minimum 20% time commitment during Phase I

fatal_flaws_to_avoid: No identified transition pathway or Phase III customer
Technology without operational relevance - solution looking for a problem
Ignoring SWaP-C constraints - size, weight, power, and cost matter
No risk mitigation for classified or controlled environments
Academic language instead of operational language
Unrealistic TRL claims without supporting evidence
Missing security considerations for sensitive work
top_15_percent_characteristics: Opens with specific capability gap referencing DoD requirements documents
Clear TRL advancement plan with measurable exit criteria
Named Phase III transition partner with letter of support
Team includes members with DoD or military experience
Risk matrix with realistic assessment and mitigation
Prior DoD contract performance cited with results
Aligned with DoD modernization priorities (JADC2, etc.)
